channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-11678] BucketCache ramCache fills heap after running a few hours
item.description: Testing BucketCache, my heap filled after running for hours. Dumping heap, culprit is the ramCache Map in BucketCache. Tried running with more writer threads but made no difference. Trying to figure now how our accounting is going wonky.
item.summary: BucketCache ramCache fills heap after running a few hours

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This seems to be working.

When we failed add an entry failing with a CacheFullException – a common occurance when heavy read load and lots of cache misses – we would drop the entry were were trying to add failing to remove it from the onheap Map. Over time the onheap Map would fill with these orphans.
What do you think about pulling the 0.98.5 RC for this fix? Leak in cache seems serious.

Andrew Purtell Lets see. I don't think it a blocker being a long-standing issue. It does seem to make bucketcache problematic in hot read when doing lots of evictions case. Wonder if our chunhui shen has tripped into this issue. Not sure I've fixed it yet either. It is looking good but want to let it run a day. Takes a while to run out of heap.

Thanks stack.

No votes have come in on the RC yet. It will be cheap to pull it as long as there aren't any. Or we can pick this up later.
Raising priority though. Seems hot read / high load is likely where this cache would be employed.

-1 overall. Here are the results of testing the latest attachment
http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12659954/0001-When-we-failed-add-an-entry-failing-with-a-CacheFull.patch
against trunk revision .
ATTACHMENT ID: 12659954

+1 @author. The patch does not contain any @author tags.

-1 tests included. The patch doesn't appear to include any new or modified tests.
Please justify why no new tests are needed for this patch.
Also please list what manual steps were performed to verify this patch.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 javac. The applied patch does not increase the total number of javac compiler warnings.

+1 javadoc. The javadoc tool did not generate any warning messages.

This message is automatically generated.

stack
We also encountered this bug recently.
The entry will not been removed from ramCache if RAMQueueEntry#writeToCache throws exception, it will cause OOM.

About the patch, we should remove the failed entries from ramCache since these entries may always be failed. e.g. the size of entries bigger than BucketCache supported(2MB as default, see BucketAllocator#allocateBlock).

So, we should add removing code after doDrain:


+            if (LOG.isDebugEnabled() && countBefore != countAfter) {

+              LOG.debug("Failed drain all: countBefore=" + countBefore + ", countAfter=" +

+                countAfter);

+            }



+ for(RAMQueueEntry ramEntry : entries){

+ ramCache.remove(ramEntry.getKey());

+ }
What does your patch look like chunhui shen out of interest? And thanks for valuable feedback. Doing as you suggest. Testing.

Ran for 12 hours. GC plot looks clean. It may be tending up slightly... will run for longer next time but looking at heap dump, this ramCache issue is no longer the culprit.

Looking to make a unit test. Its a bit awkward given how deep down doDrain is inside BucketCache but worth doing I'd say.
Managed to get a test in there for each of the modes that can happen adding item to BucketCache. Lets see what the findbugs issues are. Test failures look unrelated.

patch v2:

+        "; adjust BucketCache sizes " + CacheConfig.BUCKET_CACHE_BUCKETS_KEY +

+        " to accomodate if size seems reasonable and you want it cached.");

Nice, I like it.

+    private volatile boolean writerEnabled = true;

Why mark this volatile?

-      if (cacheEnabled

-          && (now - ioErrorStartTime) > this.ioErrorsTolerationDuration) {

-        LOG.error("IO errors duration time has exceeded "

-            + ioErrorsTolerationDuration

-            + "ms, disabing cache, please check your IOEngine");

+      if (cacheEnabled && (now - ioErrorStartTime) > this.ioErrorsTolerationDuration) {

+        LOG.error("IO errors duration time has exceeded " + ioErrorsTolerationDuration +

+          "ms, disabing cache, please check your IOEngine");

         disableCache();

I know there's no new functionality here, but shouldn't this be an RS-abort kind of offense?

+    this.bc = new BucketCache("heap", capacity, 1, new int [] {1}, writerThreadsCount,

nit: isn't "heap" and friends in an Enum somewhere? ... Oh, there's not. Probably should be.

Nice new tests. Are you able to verify that testTooBigEntry fails on current master? Maybe too much refactoring is necessary to confirm.

+1

Why mark this volatile?

Otherwise test was flakey.

I know there's no new functionality here, but shouldn't this be an RS-abort kind of offense?

It could be. The current behavior where it tries to muddle through w/o an L2 blockcache could be better in most cases (lightly loaded, serve from fscache rather than L2 cache w/ degraded perf).

Nice new tests. Are you able to verify that testTooBigEntry fails on current master? Maybe too much refactoring is necessary to confirm.

That'd have been nice.

Let me post the ugly GC graph pre-patch as substitute.

Thanks for review Nick Dimiduk
Here is how it used to run crashing after 30 minutes when violent evictions were running.

Works for me, my +1 stands.

Nice work here boss.
Thanks Nick Dimiduk Will wait see what hadoopqa says. I think there a findbugs or two in here.
